												Vegas 2 is a hard game to judge, as it's not just a game, but part of a rather prolific series. So I'll touch on Vegas 2 first for fans of the series/genre, then as its own game.So first, for other fans: you're best off looking elsewhere, Vegas is no better a tactical shooter than Modern Warfare 2, "featuring" such inconveniences as mobs of enemies, regenerating health, and a crosshair that can't be dismissed. The planning aspect is gone entirely, and the only real strategy you'll see is queueing up endless "stack up" orders on the occasional larger-than-average corridor. It's a game that pays only lip service to its forebears and altogether a bitter coda for a once great series. One is best off looking elsewhere for a proper tactical shooter.But, assuming for a moment that the game were to exist in a vacuum, with no relation to the series, then the prognosis is a whole lot more optimistic. Vegas 2 is a rather robust title with a tremendous offering of content for fans of arcade FPS. While nothing particular about the game really jumps out, it's far greater than the sum of its parts. The shooting is punchy, the weapons feel real, the locales are sufficiently varied to never feel repetitive, and your enemies are truly a force to be reckoned with. And it's the AI that really shines. Each enemy feels individual, intelligent, and dangerous; they suppress, they flank, they aggress when they have the numerical advantage, and defend when they lack it. They're not perfect, and actually seem to be artificially gimped to make them easier, but you won't find many PVE shooters with the same caliber of opponent. The actual gameplay is largely preferential, but can be roughly generalized as a slower-paced Call of Duty with fewer enemies.However, unlike Call of Duty it's a pretty robust offering of content, featuring a rather lengthy campaign (with co-op!), numerous bonus missions (co-op again!), and a lengthy--if very grindy--levelling and unlock system to keep you grinding that treadmill forever. So, a note on each. The campaign features those wacky terrorists making another attack on the biggest casinos in Vegas, and Team Rainbow is called in to clean up the mess. It's full of cheese and stupidity, being just about the campiest thing since the 50-Cent games. The plot is further hamstrung by the occasional attempts at seriousness, notably as a few VERY contrived "tearjerkers". But! It's only mildly distracting, and serves as a fine vehicle to take the player to a variety of wonderful casinos full of wonderfully dangerous prey. As for the bonus missions, they take the form of numerous big non-linear maps full of bad terrorists with guns for you to hunt down. They call it "Terrorist Hunt", why, I'll never know. The maps have a high degree of replayability, and are just good mindless fun all around, especially with a buddy. Finally is the unlock system. It's all remarkably fleshed out, allowing you to create a new operative, customize their guns, armor, clothing, camouflage, gender, face, and turn-ons/turn-offs. It's a very novel system, combining the best elements of GI Joe and Barbie Dream House so much so that customizing your vanity avatar is something of a game in-and-of-itself. By locking everything behind an XP wall, it gives you a great incentive to keep playing and something to look forward to as you progress. A lot of the weapons are locked behind that wall however, so if you're not a fan of Skinner Boxes you're gonna have a bad time.So in summary, Vegas 2 is a terrible Rainbow Six, but a pretty good and very content-rich FPS. But make no mistake, it's no more a tactical shooter than Unreal Tournament so don't expect the second coming of Rogue Spear.P.S. Play on Realistic difficulty and if you're obsessive about firearms get this mod.

												Rainbow Six Vegas 2 is a much needed improvement over the original game, and it improved aspects of the original game's design without changing very much of the overall gameplay.The biggest addition Vegas 2 added was the ability to customize your character. Instead of playing as a gruff southerner named "Logan" you instead play as a customizeable character named "Bishop". Bishop can be male or female and his/her apperance can be heavily customized. You're given the option to pick between what clothing Bishop wears and what armor you wear. Which will impact how much damage reduction you get and how fast you move. In addition Rainbow Six Vegas 2 helped start the trend towards unlock based multiplayer. Now you played as a character who was universal across Terrorist hunt and PVP. And your character would gain stats in both singleplayer and multiplayer, which would unlock new guns and cosmetics. This was really popular at the time and reminded me a lot of multiplayer games like Syphon Filter the Omega Strain. These were all great improvements and made the game feel very fresh and new. It made it feel more akin to an RPG despite leveling being automatic and the game fundamentally playing the same. The multiplayer was expanded to have many more gamemodes. And Terrorist hunt was expanded to be much more customizeable. There's actually very little I can say that's negative about Rainbow Six Vegas 2 apart from how they didn't really change very much about the actual gameplay, so it still has the same flaws like the general stiffness to the combat. The storyline is also a bit weaker. And if you're a fan of older style Rainbow Six games, you're going to remain disappointed.All that aside though, it's a very effective sequel. And there's little wonder why it's more fondly remembered than the first game.

 I played this game mainly from 2008 - 2012 on Xbox. Starting to play again but on PC this time. One of my favorite games. Much better with Keyboard and mouse of course, but the game reminds you often it was made for consoles.   TL;DR:  Weapon/armor stats don't mean jack, use what you think looks cool. Online is dead. In game weapon selection UI sucks. Great gameplay when it all works right. Tons of BS deaths. Difference between difficulties is extremely small (just play on Realistic). Majority of guns feel the same and some models are massive. Ok so real quick here. This game has problems. If you're unable to look past them I'm sorry. I love this game but in this review I'm telling it how it is.  Glitches: It's broken. I can't explain it. Just know if you get yourself into this you're gonna get mad and that pretty new razor is gonna be more like a toothpick when matched against your hulking Rainbow strength ok. I'm telling you. This game is frustrating becuase so much BS happens so often. You get used to it, and eventually it'll become just another part of the game to you. Sort of like dying in Souls. It's a fun game nonetheless, by no means a great game though. Multiplayer: Co-op with a bud is it *sad violin*. Don't worry, the multiplayer in this game wasn't the best. Customization: It's good. You getta change up your armor, very slowly unlock more as you play. I don't mind this I actually enjoy slow progression. You unlock camos for your armor (there is no camo on guns) and there are tons of camos. I try to use camos that I think blend with whatever envirorment I'm in. Most common setting is obviously an urban envirorment so I usually just use Urban camo. I like to use the Acu's too, as well as the blue russian camo. the first mission is awesome becuase you start on a snow map and everyone knows snow stealth maps in fps games are always awesome. So when you start make sure you get the snow camo going. None of this matters, it's just for your enjoyment. Doesn't effect how enemies see you at all. You can wear whatever you want. Don't pay any mind to armor stats btw. Enemies burst you down fast as heck no matter what so they're useless. Wear. What's. Dope. I'm telling you. With guns you can add 1 single attachment to each weapon. A few come standard with a sight, on those just add a different attachment that is not an optic. Story: Oh it's absolutely terrible. I'm not even gonna. I'm not. lol. It is very bad. If you play fps games for the story then don't even bother with this one. Then again, if you play fps games for the story wtf are you doing. missions/level design: Pretty simple, very predictable.  Always peak under doors  and you'll be fine. Enemies don't spawn in random spots, everything can be learned and breezed through. I look like a God when I play the first level.  psssst... Bring the SR sniper and an SMG of your choice. Remember that if you're behind cover and your crosshair is over an enemy while using a sniper, you can literally just blindfire once and it'll hit them. Or you can leave it over their head and scope in really fast. Sniping is very OP in some parts of the game.  Progression: You rank up in standard millitary ranks. E-* and whatever. You want to go for the A.C.E.S points that unlock new guns which are split into 3 categories.  Marksman (headshots, long range kills, shooting rope repelling enemies)  C.Q.B (close range, kills from behind, kills using blindfire) Assault (explosive kills, kills involving a shield, kills involving heavy weapons, shooting through cover)Stuff like that. Guns: This is where the game really lacks for me. Most the guns feel very similar to one another. I like shooters that have versatility in this area and this game is definitley lacking it. You'll feel their differences as you keep playing but the differences are small. P90 is a good gun. Aug is also very good. You'll find yourself just using AR's, SMG's and snipers. Don't be afraid to mix it up though. The Gun models are very large and bulky. The fov is quite thin.  How I have the most fun with this game: What I like to do is kind of play roles. Sniper, big machine gun man, doomguy, demolition addict, ninja. There's lots of ways to play. I love playing as a sniper with a heavily armored left arm and instructing my squad forward while I hang back and absolutely annihilate people with the SV-98 or the L96aw. It feels good. The teamwork when it works feels awesome and most the time your AI squadmates will put enemies down quick... but other times, they just kind of stare at them. It's frustrating, it really is. Wanting to love a game so badly for so long but being ♥♥♥♥ on by it so often. It's a love hate relationship, and she is one abusive  b**ch .

												Rainbow Six Vegas 2 is a direct sequel to the R6: Vegas. Kinda funny at that, as main hero is different but you control same squad. Still a tactical FPS, still without planning stage that older games had. It was released in 2008 and made by Ubisoft Montreal.It was also released for Xbox 360 and PS3. I heard that the only difference is that ability to put your face over your avatar with facecam is much improved in PC version. Oh, yes, and consoles also supported split-screen mode. No such thing on PC here.Technically, I encountered very few problem. First, quitting from gameplay into main menu would give me black screen. It was easy to fix just by alt-tabbing though. And second, I am still confused why bombs keep loudly tick even after your teammate disarms them. It's either very strange design or a bug too. It sure made some scenes quite awkward.It also has in-game achievements, but not linked to Steam. Hey, Steam overlay works now at least.As for multiplayer, it's alive. Ubisoft said something about not providing servers anymore long time ago, but the only thing it means is that you can't register new account in this game. BUT you can use your UPlay account instead, putting your email as login. And password as password.People mostly play Terrorist Hunt mode, which is incredibly fun. I also seen coop servers around, but this game was on sale not long time ago so no promises that they will stay. It supports coop only for 2 players after all, so usually people just invite their friend. There also were few versus servers, but people only play Deathmatch and Team Deathmatch now. Not every server was password protected here, good thing.And well, what can I say, it's a direct sequel and a much better PC port as well. Though this time it has global leveling system, so you aren't likely to use shield on your first playthrough. Which I am not sure that I approve. Talking of it, there is also character customization that also applies to single-player and coop, as you play as custom account called Bishop instead of Logan. And you can slap your face over the character head too. Most of the times it's going to apply eyes to forehead. Or you can apply drawing, if you are creative enough and willing to.And hey, at least this time around the game actually looks good. Much better than Vegas 1. Well, one of the reasons for that is because PC port was made with widesceen in mind this time around, supporting all the resolution. But most importantly, Ubisoft finally realized that applying brown filter doesn't make it next gen. What you mean that X360 isn't next gen anymore?Music and setting are much more varied around as well, it's not just Vegas now. Sadly, I noticed that sound seems to not always be mixed good. At least I had trouble hearing everything I am being told.Oh, and plot sucks. Alright, it's fine, but nothing amazing.There are very little new gameplay mechanic. I was dissapointed there, I surely would have loved it if they let you command two squads at same time. But nope, just one squad with same two rainbow bros. Oh well. I can easily list new features. First, you can sprint, with very limited stamina, always forgot that it exists. And more importantly, you can finally order AI teammates to throw grenades at spot you want. That pretty much means that you get 10 types of grenades for almost every type, if you can use AI effectively. Awesome. Also, look, finally have supressed sniper rifle.AI of your teammates were supposedly improved. They cover each other while advancing, one overlooking while another moves in. What I felt however is how often I would bump into their fat collision boxes while backpedalling away from corner, with them refusing to move away without order. And how slow they moved toward cover which I told them to, due to covering each other. Because on practise when you order them to get behind certain cover you usually want them to get there ASAP.Campaign itself is awesome though. Plot isn't as good, but those missions are much better. Still punishing, it feels more challenging. More good spots to use smoke grenades, sometimes more good entrances. Enemies are much more awesome, looking professional and with bad intentions, having laser sights to show off. And yep, they still show off personality, with all the behind-wall talks.Oh, and they brought enemies with shield this time around, so you know that you want to flank them while AI does frontal assault. Or abuse sniper rifle, it still works. And it still mixes open fight with room clearing, so you don't get tired of either sniping or breaching.Too bad that pre-last chapter makes you go solo. It's very hard, yes, but without teammates it's just boring sniping with smoking.Now, other modes. You can play campaign in coop with one more person if you want, seamlessly. You can't revive each other, nope. AI teammates are still around, only host can command them. It's easier with friend, yes. Especially when it ends only when both are dead in same time, you can just hide and wait for respawn.Then there is Terrorist Hunt. You can now play it with AI teammates too when in offline mode, but it still feels extremely scripted in how terrorists spawn. It's predictable and frustrating, artificial. However, once you get online, it becomes super fun for some reason. Terrorist spawn feels more natural with 4 players going around and it gets more intense, with difficulty being just right. Fear the terrorist with SPAS-12 shotgun, he is going to be your main demise. It sure gets tense when you are the last person online and there is only one terrorist left, with shotgun. You don't know where he spawned and they are really good at travelling around map.It does sometimes feel that baiting tactic work much better than actually clearing from all the sides. But oh well. Maybe it could use Hostage Rescue mode.Oh yea, there is Versus mode too. Maybe it was great in other Versus modes, but people play only DM these days. I tried. It was awful. People sprinting around, stopping only to shoot right into faces. Like other bad realistical shooters. Try to get more tactical in Team Deathmatch by overwatching territory and you are mostly likely will be called out as camper.But overall, the plot doesn't feel as interesting or urgent in this part and it doesn't have much of new, but it's still an improvement in everything else and is really good Rainbow Six title.

												Prepare to see a lot of [SPAS 12] and maybe a little bit of [UMP-45] on the killfeed.You're the one getting killed by the way.I played the 360 version of this game like 7-8 yrs ago and I pumped a LOT of hours into this game and it still manages to keep me amused. There are two things that make this game so much fun. T-Hunt (preferably with friends, realistic and high enemy density) and Customization.T-Hunt is pretty self-explanatory, there are a set number of terrorists per map and you'll have to hunt them all down. Sometimes it's easier said than done because most of those terrorists are insanely accurate and deadly especially the infamous SPAS-12 wielding terrorists.One of the greatest parts of this game is that there's a good amount of customization options for your character. You will gain XP from every kill and then eventually you'll start to gain more ranks and that means more options to customize your character with different armor, clothing and camos. Customizing your character is addicting as hell and it's kinda nice to see what kind of operators other players have made. There are of course those who run with their vomit colored tanktops looking like they are running towards the nearest convenience store getting their latest fix of their favourite energy drink. But hey, who am I to judge? If that's the character you want to create then so be it.You'll also unlock more weapons and slight XP boosts through the system called "A.C.E.S" this game has. There are three A.C.E.S trees called Marksman, CQB and Assault. The level cap for each tree is 100 but the weapon unlocks stop at 20, after that it's just an XP boost after another. You'll gain these A.C.E.S points for killing terrorists with different ways, for example, killing someone with a headshot or a kill from long range gains you some Marksman points while killing someone from close range or killing someone while blindfiring gains you some CQB points. Assault points are mostly explosives related and shooting through the walls.AFAIK the PC version is mostly the same except for a few extra bugs, the most notorious one being the sound loop bug which makes the game pretty much unplayable for off-host players. Luckily there's a fix that reduces the frequency of it happening which can be found here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/15120/discussions/0/616189106755568359/Overall it's a pretty good "tactical" shooter that still holds up. It's a shame that almost none of the recent games have this kind of customization as this game has. It's a great game to have some casual fun with friends while playing T-Hunt and also getting killed by terrorists with shotguns.AIM FOR THE HEAD

												Quality gameplay and mechanics that mesh together seamlessly to create an enjoyable and smooth experience only slightly balances out the nigh-irredeemable scars of a console port. The FOV is locked to a sub-70 angle, (and Ubisoft's excuse is quite literally saying "we cannot be arsed") meaning that a lot of the time, you're going to be killed by something you didn't see, and the controls, while fortunately rebindable, are hard to use at best and unmanagable at worst. 												A strategic, tactical FPS, this is not really the kind of game you want to play solo. While it can be done (and several do so rather fondly and have a blast), this games true potential shines with the Multi-player and character creation system.Offering 7 chapters of campaign mayhem with anywhere from three to six checkpoints, there's easily 72+ hours of gameplay if you simply try to rush through it without fully trying to enjoy the game.The Terrorist Hunt mode offers a chance to futher hone your skills and tactics for both Campaign and Online Versus modes. AI can vary from downright predictable, to completely unforgiving and brutal. Even on the lowest difficulty, the AI can stiff offer a variety of commentary and skill to throw down against the player. Again, trust not the AI paired up with you, BRING A FRIEND. Playing on Hunt? BRING THREE FRIENDS. The higher you set the scale, the harder this game can mess with you.The ability to semi-realistically alter your loadouts armor-wise is amazing. The better the armor, the heavier it is, and the slower your character can move, while taking more hits (aside from the ever annoying headshot or grenade). With multiple options for gear and weaponry, you'll be hard pressed to find someone that looks exactly alike. Word to the wise, try to pick a bright color, the enemy tends to stick to darker camo options, and you don't want to be confused for an enemy at long distances.Like any game, it does have it's quirks and glitches. Getting hit from long range with a shotgun (and it being a headshot) is downright evil. The bots also seem to have a better grasp on bullet penetration and just how to throw grenades. They also tend to spawn in random places during the Terrorist Hunts, so any areas you might have cleared, are not 100% clear. Always check your six.Definitely more than one way to complete the game, and with the option to replay quite literally from any checkpoint in the campaign, there is always something to do. If nothing else, there's always room for improvement, and even the veterans can be caught off-guard by a trick you develop. This game does deliver.

												Rainbow Six: Vegas 2 is a game I'm very passionate about, from wonderful memories playing with my dearest of  friends, to the excitement I feel whenever I rank up and unlock more equipment. Speaking of equipment, this game offers a fairly complex  loadout customization system, probably one of the most indepth systems I've ever seen in a videogame to date, though the actual avatar creator leaves much to be desired from. (Only allowing you to chose a pre-made set of skins, gender, and war paint) Gear isn't the only thing to unlock either, weapons are another aspect to look forward to, the game offers a selection from light support guns, sniper rifles, assault/battle rifles, handguns, and sub-machine guns, not to mention grenades as well as other explosive devices of varying type, making replayability quite fun, getting to create a new gear set, and try out a new weapon. The campaign can be seen as quite straightforward, though my nostalgia blinded eyes believe it's something quite special, I'll leave the decision up to you whether it's one of a kind, or generic. Besides the main story campaign, there's a fairly run of the mill multiplayer, though with the benefit of you getting to use your custom geared loadout, and a mode called 'terrorist hunt' which is a blast to play with your buddies or even just solo, as you select a map, and clear out a set number of enemy combatants, this mode is great for grinding! The soundtrack is enjoyable to listen to, the enemy A.I is somewhat competent, the guns (dependant on which you use) sound meaty and powerful, there's also fairly realistic gameplay, even if you chose the beefiest of armour, a few well placed shots from really any weapon is going to send to you to the grave, creating adrenaline filled tense moments, which could end up with a single bullet to your head, or the enemy's. All in all, I strongly recommend this game, it's a lot of fun, and should keep you busy for a while!  I hope my review can help you decide whether or not this is the game for you! ^-^

Despite all of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and the glitches, this game is one of the few games that has this level of character customization. As you play through the game, no matter what you're doing, you're ranking up what the game calls "A.C.E.S.", which unlocks new weapons and equipment, and ranking up your overall level unlocks new clothing and armor items for your character, and even a bunch of real-world accurate camouflage patterns. Not only that, but this game has a campaign that you can play fully co-operatively with a friend, and terrorist hunt mode, a returning mode from previous Rainbow Six games, which allows you and up to three buddies to take on multiplayer maps that are swarming with terrorists, the goal obviously being to eliminate them all. 												Vegas 2 has to be my favorite out of the 'Rainbow Six' franchise. You play as Bishop, a Rainbow squad leader in charge of a small counter-terrorism unit. Your mission -- to track down the dangerous Cabrero cartel in possesion of deadly chemical agents through the city of Vegas. The fun and easy squad tactics combined with the unique environments and map layouts make for some interesting scenarios in taking out the bad guys. The graphics aren't too bad for its time, and the voice acting is exceptionally well done. One of the best parts about the game is its customizable elements. From your apparel to your combat loadout, you can tweak everything to your liking.The only downsides are a limited arsenal, a drawn-out leveling process, and a boring playing experience once you've earned all the gear and acheived prestige level. The three difficulty tiers all feel the same, as well.All other things aside, with campaign, versus mode, and the additional terrorist hunt mode, this game is quite a steal for $10. It's certainly worth your time.

												Though certainly not the first game series to become worse with each new iteration, it seems that has been the trend with Rainbow Six for some time. However, even the mediocre Vegas 1 was pretty fun with it's four player co-op mode, and while a lot of the tactical elements were stripped away, we were still left with a competent, and occassionally intelligent shooter.Vegas 2 seems to take those few things that I really enjoyed about the first, removes them, and focuses more on the things that made the first Vegas not very good to begin with. Gone is four player co-op campaign (inexplicably reduced to two player), the ability to customize your soldier right out of the box (for the PC version), and decent map design. Instead, what we get was a tedious and unneccessary progression system of unlocks, AI that seems to wildly alternate between being braindead and clairvoyant, and weaker PC optimization. And not that anyone plays a Tom Clancy game for the story, but for this one, they didn't even write a new script; instead it's the same moronic terrorist attack on Las Vegas, but following a different group of Rainbows, this one even less interesting that the last.I can't think of one thing that was improved in this sequel, and a large amount of content was made worse. A lazy sequel to a mediocre game, and a lazy port for an almost entirely consolized series. My advice: if you want a good Rainbow Six game, try the original three, or if you want a less tactical game, play the original Vegas. There's nothing here that isn't offered in any of those games, and generally it is done in a way that is far less frustrating.

												This game has two faces so bare with me for this one:I love playing this game. It's fun, exciting, descent graphics, good sound (their is a !!! large warning !!! about this though, more about that later)Both the single player and multieplayer are fun to play with and things like terrorist hunt where you can multieplayer with up to 4 people with your friends to swipe a level of terrorist never gets old. Their are some minor annoyances of jittersish AI behavior: sometimes they react very slowly and other times they virtually 'teleport' around the corner and make an instant headshot. But it's more then workable, the game is beatable and enjoyable even through this.You can customize your character a lot. Their are a whole range of skins, face features (mustaches, beards eyes) and that is just the face and body. You can equip different weapon sets per game and outfit your character with stuff you can unlock through gaining levels.This leveling element has been flashed out well, their is a lot to unlock. It doesn't feel tedious because the game is well playable without a lot of unlocks. And it feels rewarding, it is just plain fun to see new stuff become available and show off your rank as well as your individual levels on assualt, CBQ and marksmen tactics.The single player has a descent story and some interesting voice acting. It's no grande feast of fully inspired epic dialog and plot. But it's very enjoyable. Sometimes it takes a bit of good luck to get your AI colleges going and doing what they need to do, but again: it is more then workable and doesn't really halt the game in my opinion.I would love to keep playing this game, although their one big BUT:Their is a persistent sound bug that keeps popping up, mainly in multieplayer . The bug seams to trigger when their is full automatic gun fire (which their is almost constantly in a heated battle) and has a chance to keep looping.Imagine the rattling of an M16 or AK rifle and that it just keeps stuck. Mostly it's a gun causing the problem laying on the ground, if you can find it and pick it up it mostly disappears. But I also found a similar bug that isn't fixable through this and in general gets worse. The former bug is location bound, when you move away the sound is gone. This big however keeps going in any part of the game (in-agem, loading screen, main menu) and can even carry on inside your operating system. I am NOT kidding, I have tried to find the volume of the game in the Win7 volume control to mute it, disabled and enabled my sound card, but the only thing that works is rebooting your whole machine.Now you might think, what does this rattling about a bug have to do in a review. Well, I am not the only one that has this bug. This bug is widely known and many, many users experience it. Their are a multietude of 'solutions' but nothing seams to stick. We have widely different system and have since we started playing all upgraded our machines or bought new ones, but the bugs stay. The internet is littered with forums etc that are filled with people with the same problem, but never a solid solution is provided.I do not understand how they have been able to make a game based on the Unreal Engine that is this flawed in the audio department. You might argue that this game is a bit older, but I don't see it that way. This game has an active community and has a lot of stuff to unlock that you can only achieve by playing it a hell of a lot. In that regard I am very disappointing in both this game and Ubisoft for not providing the community with either a statement or a solution.If this game didn't have said bug, it would be an instance classic and in my opinion can go through the decades like Unreal Tournament 2K4, Medal of Honor: Pacific Assualt, Quake 3 Arena and Battle Field 1942.It's really a game you can pick up where you left off, have a whole lot of fun, but their is always room for improvement. A pure skill game that doesn't have game mechanics that just throw off the game balance like the new COD: Modern Warfare or the newer UT and Quake games that just didn't feel like anything we loved about the orginal format.For me Rainbow Six was always a miss, because the AI was terribly stupid and the game very hard to learn in general. This game isn't, I really enjoy playing it and explore everything it has. But for some reason I have to accept that I will have to endure regular persistent automatic gun fire blazing through my headphones that NEVER STOP.

												I played the original rainbow six for the playstation in my younger days. It was a game that at the time, I couldn't necessarily comprehend fully, but I still loved it. I kept meaning to look into a game that offered me the methodical tactical based "choose where your team enters and what they do" gameplay that the original offered. I considered getting swat 4, but I felt that rainbow six was probably going to be the better choice. This however, was merely nostalgia.In this game, you cannot select where you enter a conflict. There are set spawn points for you and your team and you cannot select any other spawn points or set your own at your descretion. You also seem to have less equipment or at least less equipment that isn't context sensitive, nor does your team really function like an actual counter-terrorism team. Or anything close to that. Your team are essentially two mediocre robots that you send out to either get shot or open doors. Not only do they lack personality but they're totally unnecessary. You could probably complete this entire game on the hardest difficulty with heavy armor, a heavy machine gun and nothing else. The maps aren't very creative in the way they're layed out. They're essentially layed out like counter-strike levels with enemy bots. If you want this type of experience, I recommend looking up a half-life 2 modification called "smod tactical" as it looks and feels better. It offers much more difficulty and you actually feel like you're doing something to your enemies. This brings me to the other negative of this game. The weapons simply don't feel powerful. Even the strongest weapons in the game feel like sub-machine-guns firing nine milimetre rounds. There's no intensity, barely any difficulty, little creativity and fairly little fun.If you're one of the people who might think this game might have a good story or good writing to carry the experience, then I regret to report that this game isn't what you're looking for either. From what I remember of the campaign, it felt like a typical call of duty game. Bad guys, shoot them. Help your personality lacking goons do something. Wait at the door until the scripted event triggers to open it. It isn't that fun, as a matter of fact I'd say that a call of duty might actually be better to buy than this. The gameplay in this is less fun and the level layouts are about as linear, if not more so. This game also has the distinct feeling of being a bit of a budget title. I've not researched the game's development, so I can't tell if it is one or not, but it certainly feels that way, and for a series that I would have called one of the greatest tactical shooters of all time at one point in my life, the fact that it has reached such a low note is tragic.This game is worth just about as much as it costs. Do not expect it to really satisfy you in any real way. I wouldn't tell you to outright avoid it, but it's not that great and I abandoned playing it a quarter of the way through. Opting for instant action instead of campaign.As a word of warning, I encountered a glitch with this game that made playing impossible. At one point, the game stopped registering mouse movement. I couldn't aim, shoot, look down my sights or anything that was done through the mouse. I tried plugging my xbox 360 controller in, it wouldn't register that either.

On the title screen, it takes forever to spin your character when you drag your mouse on screen. You're not given access to every gun and outfit right at the beginning. Instead, you have to complete challenges (like shooting 10 bad guys at a long distance) that should be optional and then unlock what you want with points. Boxes can be found during missions that you can use to change your loadout and appearance. However, enemies can still come kill you while you're in the menus and the bots are useless to protect you. If you dare put the difficulty on realistic, snipers can eliminate you in one hit without clear feedback that you've been spotted.The options are in a submenu named extras when they should be visible on the first screen. The game forces you to restart after changing the aspect ratio. You can only walk from toggling and it's barely noticeable compared to moving normally. The multiplayer is unstable and you might need to host multiple times until it finally works. The logo from Unreal Engine 3 is used on Windows' taskbar and the volume mixer instead of the game's logo. - Mixed - You're forced to carry two main weapons + a sidearm. This is unpleasing from a realistic standpoint. All of your controls except movement are removed during story segments. Your name doesn't show up when you die. Instead, you're given the name of the story character. - The positive - The map and thermal vision look good. The gunplay feels nice like in Vegas 1.I've only played 1 hour of this game and I can only imagine deliberate self-harm for anyone playing through the full game.

												Excellent tactical shooter. The AI is a bit less intelligent than I would have liked, but it was still very good. I've played this for countless hours on my Xbox 360, and now several hours on the PC.One of the biggest things I like about Rainbow Six: Vegas 2 is that there are different ways to approach almost every situation. In the campaign and in single-player Terrorist Hunt, you command two other men, which allows you to plan different entrance strategies, tag enemies for your teammates to engage, and engage the enemy from different angles.The campaign is pretty well-paced and gives a good mix of opportunities to use different tactics. There are a few intense firefights spread throughout the campaign, some of which take place on a massive area where you have to utilize cover and positioning to make it through. None of the firefights can easily be done in a "run and gun" style that you would typically see in games like Call of Duty. In fact, on Realistic difficulty, you will not survive with such an attitude.Ranking is fairly intuitive. There is the classic rank (private, corporal, etc, all the way up to general), which unlocks different armor and gear (the gear is mostly cosmetic while the armor actually has stats). There are three different combat ranks as well: Assault, CQB, and Marksman. Getting certain types of kills grants points to one of the three. As you rank up in each of the three areas, you unlock new weapons and gain XP toward your main rank.Now, for some PC-specific details. The controls can be customized and re-mapped to suit you; if I recall, I actually did re-map some of the keys and am glad that this feature actually exists (I wish I could say the same for certain other games). The graphics settings are a little lacking, especially for a PC game.I don't know how populated the multiplayer on the PC is, and I might not find out for some time (ranking up takes a while, and I want my guns, dang it!). Having played Multiplayer Co-op and Versus on the Xbox360, I can attest that it's a fun break from the norm. It's more challenging than the rest of the game, and there is even different gear that you can access that can't be accessed in Terrorist Hunt or Campaign mode.I'll probably update this as I continue to play the PC version.

												It's very similar to the first one and really probably could have been released as an expansion pack. Gameplay changes inclue the ever obvious "moar guns and maps", to the addition of a sprint button, grenade indicators to let you know that it's nearby, slightly better AI that now suppress and flank you, and bullet penetration.It all sounds good, however there's no longer 4 player story mode co-op, only 2 players because for some reason the developers thought it would be better to force you to play with two AI companions for almost the entire game. The guns handle differently, so you can't as easily hit people on the move anymore so despite a sprint funciton being added, the game does play at a slightly slower pace unless you're in extremely tight spaces. Also the grenade indicator makes it significantly easier. While there's still 4 player co-op in the terrorist hunt mode, the lack of 4 player story mode is a bit of a detractor.I'll recommend it because at it's core it is a solid game with some nice co-op and level design, in some cases better than the first Vegas. However if it came down to this one and the first game in the Vegas series, I would pick the first one.
